Latin 201-1: Intermediate Latin: Prose (Fall 2022)
Barbara Lawatsch-Melton
Class notes:
Focusing on the tale of Cupid and Psyche in Apuleius, Metamorphoses, this course develops fluency and confidence in translating literary texts and an appreciation of Latin prose style.  It follows the Latin 101-102 sequence or its equivalent and reviews selected topics in Latin grammar and syntax.  We will discuss the narrative's important themes, its cultural context and reception, and the author's brilliant use of literary strategies.  In the process the course will also touch on other ancient authors and promote a deeper understanding of Apuleius, text, his time, and his legacy.
Pre-requisite: Latin 101-102 sequence or its equivalent
Required Book: Cupid and Psyche. An Adaptation from the Golden Ass of Apuleius, ed. M.G. Balme & J.H.W. Morwood  (Oxford U Press).  
Recommended: Latin dictionary, Latin textbook or reference grammar.
Grading
Two midterm tests, final exam; regular homework and class participation; several quizzes; a short presentation.
